message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: it is the intent of the spec that <video><source type=type1><source type=type2><object></object></video> won't display the <object> if the browser doesn't support either type1 or type2 videos, right? (where is this specified normatively. i could only obviously see a should-level requirement when i scanned the spec). would displaying the fallback in this case be helpful for migration from non <video> browsers without requiring a js-api for detecting

message.author: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220
message.text: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, iirc, the fallback for <video> is only intended for browsers that don't support the element at all. the spec says "content may be provided inside the video element. user agents should not show this content to the user"

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: yeah that was the requirement i found. the use case it doesn't address is the wikimedia one where you want to use <video>+ogg for firefox, want to use an applet+ogg for <video>-supporting safari and can't transcode for some reason, possibly legal

message.text: not in school at the moment, hopefully going back next year. hobbies... i play guitar, i read, i paint, i do lots of things really. sports... not a sporty person. pretty much just yoga, really which is more of a meditative stretching thing than a sports thing.

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: wonderful. so do you want to work in graphic design eventually?

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: sorry, can you hang on just two seconds? i have to leave the computer for just a minute. hang on.

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: great! you seem really nice yourself. it's hard to find nice people on here.

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: hahaha! i get the idea of what you're saying. we have sort of similar sayings too. well good for you. being single can be great. people waste so much time worrying about relationships.

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: i think so! i'm extremely lucky. usually having kids so young doesn't work out so well. i had her when i was 19, she turns 1 next month and so far it's been great being a mom : )

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: well, she was born on january 17th after a horrible labor, we got to go home 4 days later. the newborn stage was really really hard. unimaginably hard, but every month it got a little easier. first she smiled, then she crawled, then she said mama and now she's walking and talking! it's been incredible. she's such a great kid, i'm really lucky to be her mom.

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: i definitely wouldnt have planned to have her so young, but i wouldnt change anything now : )

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: oh i'm sorry if i'm keeping you up! it's still early here, so myself and the baby are just sitting on the carpet playing with our toys. her with her stuffed animals, and me with my laptop haha. nice to meet you, mirties : )

message.author: c5b9966aefea765cacbd32e08383f8df
message.text: oh jesus, i am so sorry to do this. my computer battery is at 1%, i don't know why it didn't warn me. i'm trying to type this asap so it doesn't just cut out on you. this has been such a nice chat. you are the most wonderful kid, i'm really happy i ran into you. if you happen to have facebook, my name is kate kelly, you can look me up. so sorry about this. get some sleep you! take care hun.

message.author: 4dd217ba7542bb00a127f682e2c3ad27
message.text: what is your take on the svg dependency question he raised http://www.w3.org/mid/<email/>

message.author: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774
message.text: he suggested that widget engines support svg full. make svg tiny an authoring requirement. i think it's a good idea. i was going to discuss it with shapazu and heycam. make sure everything is ok.

message.author: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774
message.text: no probs, let me fix up the spec first to see what boris says. he seems quite knowledgeable about svg

message.author: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774
message.text: it's a tricky thing. in some cases you want ws (e.g., license element) and in others you don't (e.g., name element).

message.author: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774
message.text: however, i have this gut feeling that we should be silent on this whole ws thing and leave it as an implementation detail

message.author: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774
message.text: please see my rant: http://datadriven.com.au/2008/12/08/zip-files-and-encoding-i-hate-you/

message.author: c5e3539121c4944f2bbe097b425ee774

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: lars_, but it can be a good deal more complex than that depending upon your environment, you need to read the documentation

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: i'd suggest you take a look at that

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: or if you're more textually inclined..

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: hmm. fairly small, i was going to suggest that you keep the old server online as a spare dc, best practice is to have >1.. but with that few clients..

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: basically, except you don't want to demote the old server if you want to keep it running as a domain controller.

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: you basically want to promote the second dc, probably leave it for a bit, and then transfer the fsmo roles from the old dc to the new dc, and then leave it.

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: but again, it's a little more complex depending upon your environment and you want to do things like running netdiag and dcdiag first to make sure that your domain's properly setup, so i'd read the microsoft documentation.

message.author: be461c3304e7eb09079ff7b419f5f365
message.text: i'd also make sure both dcs are configured as ad-integrated dns servers at the same time and make sure that *all* of your domain clients are given those two ips as their dns servers and nothing else.

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6: do you know if the intent is for dom3 events to have conformance criteria for the firing of events like dblclick?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: like, "when the user clicks a coordinate x,y, the user agent must fire a click event" with a description of what the event is required to be like, and what its default action should be, etc

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: also, right now the dom3 events spec says events capture and bubble on a tree rooted at the document object, but uas (well, html browsers at least) seem to do it rooted at the window, with the window owning the document -- do you know if the idea is to define that in dom 3 events too? or should i kind of "patch" dom events from html5 (where window is defined at the moment)?

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: i'd have to look at that closer, but if that's the case with current browsers, we should at least allow for that option explicitly

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: also, any evidence that would contra-indicate such changes would be great, so we are aware of what the implications would be

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: ok, well, when you post the issue, it will post to the mailing list, and then we'll hopefully get plenty of feedback

message.text: if half the people who currently validate give up because the validator complains too much, and the other half make their pages slightly better (e.g. by adding summary attributes) to please the validator, is that necessarily bad?

message.author: a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9
message.text: the validation-based quality of sites is a slope, so there would be many sites who just manage to validate now who no longer bother, whereas the "very validating" sites would probably already have made the changes

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: heycam: regarding the style sheet, i really don't want to go there. historically, we've had problems whenever specs don't stick closely to the official style sheet (e.g. css1's marble background). it also dilutes the w3c brand if the specs have different styles. i would recommend instead asking the pubteam to update their styles, so that all specs could benefit, not just hmtl.

message.text: abstract - the text about html5 is a bit confusing and perhaps not particularly relevant for a high level abstract. if anything at all must be said at this point in the document re html5 (and i recommend it be removed), i would just say something like "the specification describes the widget interface and other dependencies, including:" and remove the "persistent storage" bullet.

message.author: 4dd217ba7542bb00a127f682e2c3ad27
message.text: re section 1.1 - i would remove the following sentence until the document actually exists:"the widgets 1.0: security model [widgets-security] specification defines a security model that defines what a widget can or cannot do at runtime."

message.author: 4dd217ba7542bb00a127f682e2c3ad27

message.text: i sell myself short

message.text: your long lost love

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: would you want to be immortal

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: suppose that people live forever. strangely, the population of each city splits in two: the laters and the nows. the laters reason that there is no hurry to begin their classes at the university, to learn a second language, to read voltaire to newton, to seek promotion in their jobs, to fall in love, to raise a family.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: for all these things, there is an infinite span of time. in endless time, all things can be accomplished. thus all things can wait. indeed, hasty actions breed mistakes. and who can argue with their logic? the laters can be recognized in any shop or promenade. they walk an easy gair and wear loose-fitting clothes. they take pleasure in reading what ever magazines are open, or rearranging furniture in their homes, or slipping into conversation the way a leaf falls from a tree.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: the nows not that with infinite lives, they can do anything they can imagine. they will have infinite number of careers, they will marry an infinite number of times, they will change their politics infinitely. each person will be a lawyer, a bricklayer, a writer, an accountant, a painter, a physician, a farmer.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: the nows are constantly reading new books, studying new trades, new languages. in order to taste the infinities of life, they begin early and never go slowly. and who can question their logic? the nows are easily spotted. they are the owners of acres, the college professors, the doctors and nurses the politicians, the people who rock their legs constantly whenever they sit down.the move though a succession of lives, eager to miss nothing.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: the nows and laters have one thing in common. with infinite life comes an infinite list of relatives. grandparents never die, nor do great-grandparents, great-aunts and great-uncles, great-great-aunts, and so on, back through the generations, all alive and offering advice. sons never escape from the shadows of their father. nor do daughters of their mothers. no one ever comes into his own.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: when a man starts a business, he feels compelled to talk it over with his parents and grandparents and great-grandparents, ad infinitum, to learn from their errors. for no new enterprise is new. all things have been attempted by some antecedent in the family tree. indeed, all things have been accomplished. but at a price. for in such a world, the multiplication of achievements is partly divided by the diminishment of ambition.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: and when a daughter wants guidance from her mother, she cannot get it undiluted. her mother must ask her mother, who must ask her mother, and so on forever. just as sons and daughters cannot make decisions themselves, they cannot turn to parents for confident advice. parents are not the source of certainty. there are one million sources.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: where every action must be verfified one million times, life is tentative. bridges thrust halfway over rivers and then abruptly stop. buildings rise nine stories high but have no roofs. the grocer's stocks of ginger, salt, cod, and beef change with every change of mind, every consultation. sentences go unfinished. engagements end just days before weddings. and on the avenues and streets, people turn their heads and peer behind their backs, to see who might be watching.

message.author: d6669f2ac5944406185198c07c89ee06
message.text: the diminishing marginal utility of life would decrease to such a low point where one could no longer feel life.

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: do you think it would be fine to define the new methods as if they passed a documentfragment to our existing methods?

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: 8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81: e.g. append("test", node) passes a documentfragment consisting of a text node "test" and a node to concept-node-append

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: i'm not sure why we should support document.append(documenttype), but some people think we should

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: of course it also means document.append(documenttype, element) should work (if document does not have them), but that requires changes to the existing algorithm

message.text: https://foursquare.com/business/brands/offerings/savetofoursquare

message.author: 3c1a153d81002878b83df957ee534f47

message.author: 3c1a153d81002878b83df957ee534f47
message.text: this is very cool, foursquare essentially has an hcard-based web action button that you can use to allow users to collect places to visit.

message.text: perhaps the category of "read later" web actions need be broadened to "do later"‚ä¶ hmmm

message.author: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: you'd hit "if the current section has no heading, let the element being entered be the heading for the current section."

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: i don't see how you can hit this clause without a previous section

message.author: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: we don't change candidate section until then, so, what? the section before candidate section in the current outline?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: the only way you can hit this i think is <body><h1/><h2/><h2/>

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: in which case you can always go up to the <h1>'s section

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: it'll always work because the one case where it would fail is handled as the first "otherwise" for heading content (before this sublist)

message.text: its not about whether i care, its about what matters to you. you don't need to go away for 6 months to figure that out from a bunch of bible belt ultraconservative freak shows.

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: people get depressed, and some have it harder than others. i went through a really bad stage in my life as well, and was even hospitalized for it. and i did have it really bad, but literally nothing anyone in there said or did changed my mind about my depression. and i can guarantee no one in there will do it for you. only you can change your mind about how you feel; and i can give you a good start:

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: you first must recognize that some people do have it bad, i mean, your mother ran out. and that's a terrible thing to have happen: but you know what, no one will fully understand what you've gone through. i can't begin to fathom what that was like, or how i would feel. but i can also tell you that you'll become a stronger person for it if you let yourself, and above anything and all else in this world, above your christian god and your forsaken mother, you can be proud of yourself. you can be proud of yourself. you will have done something to take pride in.

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: your future is the most important thing that america has right now, and you can be proud of that. america won't thank you for it, they may never acknowledge your even alive, but i really believe that the best feelings of worthfulness come from inside; the realization that you, yourself, have broken through this barrier, and that you're going to keep on kicking even if the bubble seems unbreakable. because as long as you are you, make the right choices, then it doesn't matter if the rest of the world recognizes you for it, what truly matters is that you recognize yourself for it

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: you won't get through it at all if you can't get through it on your own. how can anyone else help you overcome your problems in life when literally no one understands what you're going through? they're not you, never will be, will never fully understand the depth and complexities that make you, you. but, that doesn't mean your helpless, that just makes you stronger for your ability to cope and overcome. you don't need anyone else for that.

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: you can never know, or expect to know where help comes from

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: you can write me off as a messenger from god, an apparition of fate, whatever, the fact is, i'm here, i have said what i've said because i meant it, and what you do from here on out is on you. it's on you. you have accountability, responsibility, again, even if no one else ever recognizes it. we are all only as depressed as we let ourselves to be. and sometimes, depression can be the right path to go down. being depressed over your mom leaving isn't a bad thing, don't ever let someone tell you your weak for having those feelings, or having any feelings at all. because those are your feelings, and you can feel how you want; you are you. and no one else will ever understand that.

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: you want to know what my biblical-equivalent of an epiphany was?

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: i was stationed in this hospital because one day, after fathoming the afterlife and the metaphysical world as i knew it, i came to the single conclusion that all philosopher's before me had come to when it comes to the purpose of life: that there simply was none, and that death was just as much a viable solution as any. so, i contemplated, by waving a knife around my neck, what all would happen if i grazed a little deeper, when my parents came in and had a fit. long story short, winded up at the hospital, where i spoke to counselors, brothers and grandmas of counselors, shrinks, and other kids with my behavior. and not a single one of them directly had anything to do with the realization that i came to one day that, suicide may have been a viable solution, but, who was i to make that choice? would it perhaps give me some form of honor, albeit only held within my own mind and heart, that i was going to overcome all obstacles, purely for the sake of overcoming them? and i decided it would, that i could be proud of my decision, to uphold an honor code that only i was aware of, that i would live a life, my life, for myself, and no one else. and then...

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: i spoke to a dream counselor about a dream i had, involving me in a beach house overlooking a cliffside view over a blue ocean, in a semi-circular room, and said that this was what i wanted in life. that anything that happens in my life was a means to an end, and that end was for this moment. and he said "you don't belong here. you're not crazy, you just know what you want. and you should be proud of that, because there are only a handful of people on this earth that can truly say that. that makes you, you. and that's something to be proud of."

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: i'm not in the best of places right now, not a single thing is going how i want it to or i how planned, but in the end, i'm still myself. and i can't, i won't complain about that. that is absolutely no reason to be depressed about that.

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: and if you have access to this particular musical song, maybe its on youtube, i'll take a look, definitely take a really close listen, because literally everything that comes out of this guys mouth is pure truth about how to live and fully understand you're life

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: there's the link: the name of the song is called "everbody's free (to wear suncsreen)" by baz luhrman.

message.author: 21117c07c26c9ff34f6057f5bc3b4bdc
message.text: my internet is acting up; its time to say goodbye. even if tomorrow, you change your entire opinion about everything, you can at least go on knowing this moment happened. again, my point was never to influence you, but just to expose you. expose you to hopefully something you realize as greater than yourself, something that isn't worth being depressed about anymore. thanks for letting me chat with you, and i bid you the best of luck in your endeavors. sincerely, ntb.

message.text: i guess it comes down to </head> being ignored but only being a parse error sometimes and <title> being treated like a normal element except for its content model

message.text: ok, if you could update the wiki with what you see as a sort of spec roundup and roadmap (for the specs you are involved in) that would help

message.text: changes: mike: checkpointed after incorporating some schema updates <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2010nov/0049.html> ** hixie: make form submission via .submit(), and page navigation via location.href, when either is done before the page has completely loaded, result in a history replacement (like a redirect) rather than a regular load. (whatwg r5685) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2010nov/0048.html

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: changes: mike: added documentation for the s element <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2010nov/0051.html> ** hixie: change pushstate() and replacestate() so that they update the pending state object as well (otherwise, pushstate vs pushstate;back;forward would result in different state objects in the initial popostate which is just silly). (whatwg r5686) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2010nov/0050.html>

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: once you know a processing key that's used on a disc (which is typically the same for all discs), you can combine that with some other disc-specific data to end up with the keys that decrypt the actual data; at least until new discs are manufactured with new processing keys, in which case you have to start all over again and try to discover the new keys.

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: at least it's a readable published specification, and the security depends entirely on the keys being kept secret, which is how cryptography ought to work - the problem is that it's impossible to keep the keys secret, and it has statements like "a device shall keep the value s_0 confidential, as defined in the license agreement" which doesn't work quite so well when millions of customers have your devices and want to extract the secret values

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: (or maybe i should fix my ocaml tokeniser generator, and then generate an html5lib-compatible tokeniser, so it's easier to attempt fancier optimisations like inlining stuff to avoid function calls)

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: how will you do readahead one token at a time?

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: also, if what's checked in has test faliures in the tokenizer other than ones related to non-bmp unicode characters then i probably have changed something there

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: by looking ahead one character, and if it's not what was expected then unget it, otherwise look ahead one more character, and if it's not what was expected then unget the latest character and do something special to the first character (like emit it as a character token or whatever is appropriate)

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: oh, i haven't actually run the tokeniser tests, i just assumed it hadn't been updated when the spec was changed to add mathml and suchlike

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yes, because if you're not going to treat it as an entity then you're going to (output it as a character token | append it to the attribute value), so you can do those directly with the list of characters you've collected inside the entity function instead of ungetting and passing control back to some other state

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: i think it does. basically you just end up buffering characters locally inside the state rather than globally, right?

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: i get quite a few doctype wrong-number-of-parseerror test failures - is that something you fixed locally?

(whatwg r6114) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2011may/0076.html> ** hixie: typo (whatwg r6113) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2011may/0075.html> ** microdata; hixie: clarify how to generate ifragment thingies (whatwg r6112) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2011may/0074.html

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: bugmail: [bug 12351] consider changing 'the same object' to 'the same such object' when talking about live objects in various places in the spec, for pedantism... <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0466.html> ** [bug 12350] should mention that in the "parents" column, categories refer to elements that _expect_ that category, not elements of those categories... <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: changes: hixie: correctness (whatwg r6116) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2011may/0078.html> ** hixie: change how document[name] works to be compatible with both ie (which typically are targetted with <object>) and other uas (which typically are targetted with <embed>). (whatwg r6115) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2011may/0077.html>

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: bugmail: [bug 12091] htmldocument named-item getter and object fallback <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0475.html> ** "[bug 12350] should mention that in the "parents" column, categories refer to elements that _expect_ that category, not elements of those categories..." (2 messages in thread) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0474.html> ** [bug 12332] editorial: http://html5.org

message.text: columbo: some people like having the whole webapp in exactly one file, and never more than one file, but the reasons for wanting that aren't real sound.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: columbo: if disk space is the reason, that might make sense. if the webapp is really huge, and deploying it as a single file is a must, then you don't want to duplicate the entire webapp by also unpacking it at deployment time.

message.text: (which could be bad if we don't accuratley anticipate how <header> will be used)

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: which is the reason why it might make sense to resist the kind of text/html extensibility that'd bring xml-style namespacing to html

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 - i think more people would see value in adding a general extensibility mechanism if it there were any problem cases other than dealing with svg for which it would address any real market/user demand

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: extensibility mechanisms that didn't solve any specific existing or forseeable problems were what the sgml guys specialized in

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: and we can see how far it got them

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: i agree. though i do see a little bit of market demand for mathml integration as well (to the extent there's mathml demand in the first place).

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: but perhaps the html case is different in that we know it's going to be around for good while longer, so building extensibility mechanisms for future possible down-the-road problems may not be as much of a waste of time as it turned out to be for sgml (now that sgml is dead and most people think it's good riddance)

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: design principle: don't try to get too far ahead of the implementor requirements and user requirements...

message.author: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
message.text: how many authors want to use week or ordinal dates?

message.author: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
message.text: calendar dates are fine. i see no reason to allow week/ordinal dates.

message.author: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
message.text: i'd be tempted to somewhat ruthlessly apply the 80/20 rule here, and disallow week/ordinal dates, which allow nothing that can't be given as a calendar date

message.author: 3c1a153d81002878b83df957ee534f47
message.text: introducing limitations like that makes it harder for authors to keep track, whereas "iso8601 dates are valid" is easier to remember.

message.author: 3c1a153d81002878b83df957ee534f47
message.text: iirc rfc3339 also requires seconds to be specified on datetimes, which is also silly, given authors rarely do that.

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: you should switch it to utf-8 and if you don't see any problems just keep it that way

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: benschwarz: i think any difference you see in mobile safari or other browsers is due to what philip` mentioned

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: that is, their html parsers don't know about the header element

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: they don't know that <header> implies a <body> start tag

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: so another way to solve that is not use <header>

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: but instead use <div class=header> or something

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: but i find no header element in the source nor any part of anolis or the splitter that generates one

message.author: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220
message.text: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6, do you have any idea why the directors call for selectors api ended up being done without me?

message.author: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220
message.text: i never heard a thing about when it was supposed to be, and now i see the mails on member-webapps saying that it's already been done.

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: sorry if i miscommunicated... normally, the editor is not involved at all, but we were not hearing back from chaals, and we were trying to get it done before the end of the year, so plh suggested we see if you could stand in for chaals

message.author: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220
message.text: really? i thought the editor was always supposed to be in on those calls

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: until just a couple years ago, not even the chairs were involved, it was just the director, the domain lead, and the team contact

message.author: f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220
message.text: although, fwiw, it would be better if, when v2 was ready for rec, it would just be called "selectors api" and simply replace v1, if the w3c process actually allowed for that, but i don't think it does

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: i wanted to ask you about cross-site post and the reason for having two access checks (first for the get and then for the post); simply for being on the safe side right?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: do you mean specifically for post or for anything other than get?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: the reason we require a preflight on delete and other verbs is that historically there has been no way to perform such actions on remote servers with the user's credentials without the user's consent

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: the first check is to see if we can send

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: the second is to see if we can read

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: mnot's point about <?access-control?> seemed sort of valid btw, though for convenience it's much better than access-control: ... for which you either need to write a script (which complicates caching) or do arrange it in a separate file (.htaccess and addheader)

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: as brad pointed out, hosting providers aren't everything

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: there are many systems where it is non-trivial to add a header

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: (not to mention that adding headers is far beyond some people's abilities, while adding a pi by copy and paste it not)

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: here's an interesting question. i say that the "box" referred to throughout the rules is simply a rectangle the same size as an svg image without intrinsic dimensions (in background situations, that's the size of the background bounding-box). however, once that's calculated, it doesn't change. if you used background-position to *move* the gradient image, it shouldn't adjust to the...

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: frex, radial-gradient(ellipse farthest-side, red, blue) should create a gradient that turns blue *right* at the box edges. but if i then do background-position: 100px top (in a 200px wide box) it'll instead look like a half-ellipse, correct?

message.author: 3c1a153d81002878b83df957ee534f47
message.text: do you have the diff url of makacow's change(s) to rel-license?

message.author: fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98
message.text: "as more contributors add a public domain declaration to their user pages, and more non-public-domain content is removed, more pages fully enter the public domain. after reviewing such pages, the microformats admins will add the http://microformats.org/wiki/template:cc-pd-license template to them to explicitly indicate that all content of the page is in the public domain."

message.author: 3c1a153d81002878b83df957ee534f47
message.text: well this is particularly easy, i just checked w3.org and w3.org's news page, and there is no presence of rel="details" so i'm simply going to remove (undo) makacow's edit in its entirety as it doesn't add any real world information.

message.text: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: do you have http header data for anything apart from the 15k dmoz dataset?

message.text: i.e., <header name="date" uri="http://www.grebe-gt.de/" value="wed, 12 dec 2007 00:19:58 gmt"/> within root xml_grep element

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: (the <header> bits are the same, but the root is <survey> and it has <processed> and <redirect> and <error> stuff)

message.text: i want to minimise time taken to transfer across internet + time to compress + time to decide how to compress

message.text: http://www.cl.cam.ac.uk/~pjt47/misc/output-headers.xml.bz2 (10mb)

message.author: a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554
message.text: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: what's wrong with <!element survey ((processed, redirect?, header+) | error)*>?

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: so if you're ignoring attribute values, the element ordering is basically completely unstructure

message.text: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: if it is interleaved, how does processed mean anything?

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: hmm. was <command> in <head> forbidden earlier?

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: i've marked <command> in <head> nonhtmlizable but i don't find explanation in the spec.

message.author: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0
message.text: treating unknown tags as empty elements when found in head (like firefox does) makes <command> in head nicer for legacy uas

message.author: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0
message.text: though i don't like firefox's way of deciding whether something is "in head" or not

message.author: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0
message.text: which depends on whether there was an actual <head> start tag

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: yeah, this explains it: http://parsetree.validator.nu/?doc=http%3a%2f%2fhsivonen.iki.fi%2ftest%2fmoz%2fcommand-in-head.html&submit=print+tree

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: i guess i should mark <event-source> in <head> nonhtmlizable as well

message.author: cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: amazon s3 apparently already lets you set custom http headers for your files, so i think you could just add a "access-control-allow-origin: *" and it'd be fine

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: i compared prices on xen hosting, and this is what i learned

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: finds it odd that dreamhost advertises a $5.95/month rate, which only applies if you pay for ten years in advance, which is almost as long as the html5 timetable - who's going to know they're still going to want a web server that far in the future?

message.author: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9
message.text: i want to see this area of business evolve into a model where someone own the datacenters and provides xen paravirtualization and block storage, then someone else provides as open source on top of that app engine -like automatic scaling so that the system is commodity open source and you can move to a different service provider

message.text: disappointment is easier to work with. yeah you made a mistake, and you've obviously learnt your lesson and won't do it again right?

message.text: i know. and i can see that. and honestly, i respect you for doing that. alot of people wouldnt do that.

message.text: you need to be strong though, im sure you are. im hoping that your sister will stand behind you when/if you tell your parents.

message.text: dont bloody harm youself! im really anti it. ive lost a few friends like that and i dont want you to waste your lfie

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: really. i dont want to make this about me, but i was on the verge of taking my own life when i was 13 when some stuff happened.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: you need to think about who your going to hurt if you do that, who you're going to leave behind having to try heal.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: when i was 13, i was home alone, then my grandma came home, about 5minutes later she collapsed and i had to perform cpr on her, i didnt know what i was doing. by the time the ambulance got there, there was no pulse, but they managed to revive her. about 6 hours later in hospital. they pronounced her dead.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: i still live with guilt. that if only i knew what to do, maybe she would still be here, seeing that day replay itself in my head everyday

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: everyone told me that. but i couldnt help what i felt. i still feel guilty now, and im 18. the guilt isnt as bad. but its still there.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: neither was what happened to you. you were only trying to help.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: and you know, since that happened, my view on everything has changed, you only life once, you cant take life for granted, and (excuse my language) but shit happens.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: tell them that. say that the other guy that was going to take them was far too drunk.

message.author: 169ecde7f3998f897129bbe806c980fb
message.text: i have to go now. i hope everything works out for you, i hope i helped? im not good at this stuff. but i really do hope that it all works out, im sure your parents will be upset and the start, but then start to slowly deal with it. take care ok? please, please, dont do anything silly!

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: f-s-a takes a number between 0 and 1. it multiplies that by the declared font-size of the element to get a desired x-height. it then adjusts the *used* font-size for all the fonts so that their x-height matches that number.

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: there's plans to also add an 'auto' value that somehow figures out what the 'default' font is supposed to be, and figures out what the f-s-a number should be based on that font's x-height.

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: <section> is just a special flavor of <div>. it resets your heading levels and should have a heading itself.

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: a heading is <h1-6>, possibly grouped with an <hgroup>.

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: oh, anything can fall in a section. like i said, it's just a special flavor of <div>. using <section> rather than <div> indicates that the contents form a coherent section of the document/application, and it would make sense to make this a line in a document outline.

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: yeah, that's potentially correct, as long as that <canvas> would be part of an actual *section* of your document. if you just need a container element around it, like for css purposes, then use <div>.

message.author: 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb
message.text: again, if you're not giving the <section> a heading, you probably shouldn't use it.

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: (getkind() et all is also slightly nicer from my standpoint because there's no extra object to worry about, so no lifetime issue, no edge cases to define like "what if you keep a reference to a track and ask for its kind after the video has changed number of tracks"

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: and you can also call new mediastream(userstream) which returns a new mediastream, call it secondstream

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: and you wouldn't want to be able to take track objects from the htmlmediaelement.videotracks list

message.author: 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427
message.text: what if you build a stream out of tracks, start playing it somewhere, and then change the media resource in the htmlmediaelement you got the tracks from?

message.author: 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427
message.text: the approach where you create a mediastream that takes another stream as input and selects different tracks fits nicely with my work

message.text: bugmail: [bug 10250] new: why must context menus not reflect changes in the dom? maybe some browsers want to always show the possible actions for an element. in order to do this they would have to regularly fire the contextmenu event to update it reflecting changes in the dom. <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2010jul/0471.html>

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: zcorpan: quoted should be theoretically a tiny bit faster for long attribute values, since you don't need to keep checking for whitespace, but maybe a tiny bit slower for short values since the quotes mean there are more characters to process, but i think that's all trivial and irrelevant compared to all the other costs (of getting input characters in the first place, of constructing attribute value strings, etc)

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: the extra 2 bytes for a quoted attribute, if you're downloading a web page at 100kb/sec, would take about 20 microseconds, which is about 40,000 cpu cycles, so a few extra comparison instructions won't be at all significant

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: depends on who is sufficiently an html5lib guy for your requirements

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: i don't believe i've heard anybody intending to try that any time soon

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: though i suppose it's nice to make browsers do standards instead of almost standards

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: i think the point is to make old content work the same as if it used an old standards mode doctype (e.g. xhtml strict), and also to be as short as possible

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: the way i did it with the tokeniser was to create a load of short (mostly 1 character) strings, run the tokeniser algorithm on all of them, then remove the ones that were redundant (i.e. resulted in exactly the same tokeniser state), then made a load more slightly-longer strings by appending short strings to each of the ones from the previous stage

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: that requires the ability to run the tokeniser algorithm and see what state it ends up in - i have no idea if you can do the same with html serialisation

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: i don't maintain gentoo. it's too broken. the guy who says he does maintain the gentoo tomcat package comes in here once in a while.. yes, obsidian.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: okay. he's a great guy, and spends lots of time on this stuff.. but, he can't really fix gentoo either.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: gentoo is fundamentally broken with regard to java programs like tomcat.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: well, the way you're trying to deploy your webapp sounds like it's fine, although i can't see everything you're doing.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: but, i've expressed serious concerns to obsidian that packaging tomcat in gentoo the gentoo way will render tomcat broken.. and it appears that i'm right.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: probably take you 5 mins. :)

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: but also, beware that the only result that tells you something solid is the case where the official tomcat works fine. if it doesn't work fine, that doesn't tell you a thing, since there may be environment variables that gentoo sets that screw up the official scripts.

message.author: 2a78e4ddb897d821d45a3ba9ce2078d5
message.text: okay. i have to go to sleep.. so when you have the answer, just type it in here or a private message to me, please! :)

message.text: so i tried to push a changeset from csswg.org/test

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: fwiw, if you're making changes in one of the subrepos, you can just push there...

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: that should probably be in a subrepo so it can rev independently of the entire site (and we can give other people access to it without giving them the whole web server)

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: i can set that up after lunch today if you want

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: yes, that was what i was going to work on after lunch

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: not really, i was going to give my copy another once over, push it to our mirror, then ask you to double check it

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: once you give the nod i'll push to dvcs.w3.org and we can shut down the cvs repo

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: i just need to get some lunch first, learned the hard way not to make important system changes on low blood sugar :-)

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: updating your tree, making the change, checking the diff, pushing it to the repo, resolving conflicts

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: but there should basically be two sets of commends to run: stuff before i make edits, and stuff after i make edits

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: "how do i update my tree" and "how do i push my changes"

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695: also, a significant number of our spec editors don't use the command line

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: while i'm not opposed to good documentation, part of me wonders if we're over thinking this, i'd think spec editors would be more dvcs savvy than test authors, and what we had for the test repo was ok then...

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: imo there's enough documentation explaining mercurial already on the web, our docs should only focus on the specific issues of working with our repo and should point to other existing docs

message.author: 0727cf52ad9f560d45e18372943ed695
message.text: i hear you, and i'll work on it this afternoon. i just don't want to go crazy with hg docs.

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, does the spec yet define what a "browsing context keyword" is?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: but the term "browsing context name or keyword" is defined

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, ok, i see now, "a valid browsing context name or keyword is any string that is either a valid browsing context name or that case-insensitively matches one of: _self, _parent, or _top."

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: the two terms are "browsing context name" and "browsing context name or keyword", i didn't intent there to be a "browsing context keyword" term

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, fwiw, it seem like the sentence "the rules for chosing a browsing context given a browsing context name are as follows." should be "the rules for chosing a browsing context given a browsing context name or keyword are as follows."

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: "browsing context identifier"?

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: i would like to see a proposal for that smaller api

message.text: bugmail: [bug 9813] new: bgsound: use "audio" instead isn't helpful for back-compat. proposal: use "audio" instead, with "embed" fallback for backwards compatibility <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2010may/0444.html>

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, i think <video> needs height= / width= as convenient shorthands

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: people expect <font> to work, doesn't mean we should encourage it. we have the opportunity here to prevent abuse, why not take it?

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: i'm not sure how height= and width= would be that harmful given that <video> allows the content to be played independently from the browser

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: for the common case you want height=/width=

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: you keep saying that but i don't see why

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: i think you want it on both

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: why? i've given you several arguments against, so far your argument in favour has just been that you think you want it :-)

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: (would you also want align="" on <p>?)

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: given how well that works with css, that's a whole other ball game

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: i mean, why would you want height/width and not bgcolor=""?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: or would you want that too?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: ohhh, i think i see where our assumptions are differing

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: and i don't see why two of the properties would be special cased when everything else has to go into <style> blocks.

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: we want to encourage good authoring practices.

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: anyway, i should go to bed

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: so, role="fancybutton button listitem" is not clear... should button be a fallback for fancybutton? how can you tell they are related? should listitem be honored?

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: can you have a fancybutton listitem?

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: 1) you want to provide a list of alternatives (in fallback order)... "pick one that you support, then stop"

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: 2) you want to provide a list of all possible combinations (probably unordered)... "this is an dropdown and a tree and a checkbox control"

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: but what if it does know both fancybutton and button, and they are mutually incompatible, and it tries to supply both?

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: what if it does know fancybutton?

message.author: 227a9a17d1db3f8e5c71a150345fb2a6
message.text: i'm not opposed at all to your approach, i just have to play devil's advocate to think things through, make sure we're not missing something

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: maybe nobody thought to set one up yet

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: the answer to the "is schema.org a standards body like the w3c or ietf ?" question in the faq is interesting

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: every new standards body seems to start out with an assertion that it's not a standards body

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: but it's hard to see how an organization set up to provide and maintain a standard set up schemas is not actually a de facto standards body

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: "changing to the new markup format could be helpful over time because you will be switching to a standard that is accepted across all three companies"

message.author: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
message.text: as far as i can see at this point, it seems like schema.org is not any more of a formal organization that whatwg.org is

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: also... don't make the mistake of thinking microformats are tied to classnames. different ones use different elements/attributes based on what is correct semantically

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: <div class="vcard" id="main-document" role="document">

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: a div wrapping the whole document? that's sort of evil

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: that sort of thing should be in an <aside> probably :) any anyway, this is a div wrapping the entire <body>

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: all the sections/articles in body are the content of a page...

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: sure... hence the body-level <header>

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: why? home is a part of the heading for all the everything on the page

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: if that's semantically what you want, then yes. there is no need for that usually

message.author: c74f596e4fe95fc3bb8726dbde2031b0
message.text: yes, just not *all* of them. any time every single thing in body is in one tag, it's probably wrong... <body> can contain content for a reason

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: if you're using the html5 parser and you're serving as text/html, then it will parse as html5 and not as xml

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: it will apply to the elements you want it to apply to only as long as you're parsing the document under an html5 parser *as html*

message.author: 3f21e54c5c5ffd50fe3680acc025bb1d
message.text: 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: then xml parsing rules take effect, and unless you declare a namespace it won't exist

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: wonders if there could be getimagedata(sx, sy, sw, sh, hires) where hires=true makes it return the full-resolution backing bitmap with width!=sw, otherwise it scales the bitmap down and returns with width==sw

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: so people who don't know or don't care can just do getimagedata(sx, sy, sw, sh) and get what looks like sensible pixels, whereas people who really want to do high-quality filters can set hires and take more care

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: so people who just want to assume canvas pixels are really pixels can do so, and they'll get some visual degradation if they start doing get/putimagedata, but it'll do what they expect

message.text: why would it be any different to drawing a static image, except that it uses the current frame at the time when you call drawimage?

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: bugmail: [bug 8414] new: shouldn't the example pattern be "^[0-9][a-z]{3}$"? the current example would succeed with any string containing a part number, and not just a string that is one. <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2009dec/0032.html>

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, i can't find a spec that defines that when <link rel=stylesheet href=test> returns content-type:text/html it can't be parsed as css

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: also, i don't think it's acceptable for other browsers to fix that bug in a way that firefox handles it

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: but i can't see anything telling me whether content-type: bogus is a given type or not

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: i don't think we should ever treat a text/html file as a stylesheet

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: but i agree that bogus should be treated like text/html

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: why would we want a quirks there?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: there are lots of css files sent as not-text/css last i checked

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: i have a lot of trouble, i just can't see any way to save it

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: the problem with css is that text/html files often end up containing css inline, and if you apply that to the other doc, it usually isn't what you meant to do

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: i just don't see that we can convince the httpwg to do so

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: so if we decide that the case of <link rel=stylesheet> pointing to a non text/css file is non-conforming but nevertheless must be treated as text/css they are probably happy

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: b7a6377567c24010a269d96f216a9255, so it sounds like the "fullscreen flag" really ought to be on top-level browsing context instead of document if all documents need to have it set

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: i guess my idea was that all documents would be fullscreen if their top-level browsing context is fullscreen

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: it seems to me that removing an element that is the fullscreen element should simply clear the fullscreen element for that document and the fullscreen element of any descendant browsing context documents (if any)

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: then for the scenario where a new element becomes the fullscreen element i think nicest would be to find the nearest common ancestor fullscreen element of old and new, remove all old and dispatch events and then set new and dispatch mutation events

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: the alternative would be to clear "fullscreen element" everywhere, set it anew, and dispatch fullscreenchanged on all documents

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: i would suggest to read http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#interactive1 carefully although i suppose you have already done so... :)

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: click is dispatched of which the default action is to dispatch domactivate

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: and the first element with activation behavior it bubbles through (in the first case, <button>, second case, <a>) will have its activation behavior triggered (submission, following the link)

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: it just defines what the default action of click and domactivate is

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: for click -> dispatch domactivate; for domactivate -> activate the first element with activation behavior in reverse tree order

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: for instance, the <a> element is defined to have activation behavior which would be triggered if anyone click on "foo" in the following cases <a>foo</a>, <a><span>foo</span></a>, <a><span>bar<span>foo</span></a>, etc.

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: (well, i see that in gecko you could get multiple domactivate events now because of how <a>.onclick is handled right now...)

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: bb21c722adad611b63dfb48ec99e8350, yes, the default action of a click event being dispatched is to dispatch a domactivate event

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: i suppose html 5 should just be clarified that the click event only does that when the current node is also the target node

message.text: css extensions, dom extensions and mathml all involve putting a short prefix into the opaque name

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: i think <a> should be allowed to wrap around "block level elements" and i think that adding href everywhere complicates processing models too much for no real benefit

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: why does it make the processing model any more complicated than it already has to be to handle global onclick and :hover?

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: because every element gains an additional default click event handler

message.author: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e
message.text: (that might conflict with existing click event handlers (in case of form controls) so you need to make choices how to handle those, etc.)

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: ah, sounds like the issue is that e.g. a <button> currently has one default click handler and n dom click event handlers, and <button href> would change that to be >1 default click handler rather than changing it to n+1 dom click event handlers

message.author: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
message.text: another issue is you'd sometimes want the other link-related attributes like rel and target and ping, and you'd have media and hreflang and type too for consistency, which would get messy

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: operationally - seems like a fair bit of difference between "mandatory non-error warning" and "you can choose to make all of them errors or all of them silent with a flag inside the document"

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: the difference between "your document is valid but uses some obsolete features" and "tour document is validates as html transitional" seems rather subtle to me. presumably the majority of authors using transitional doctypes know that they are using obsolete features

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: but hey, maybe calling them "transitional features" instead of "obsolete but conforming features" might be better branding

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: they should be called this-is-a-bad-idea-and-you-don't-want-to-do-this-but-hey-experience-suggests-that-you-will-do-anyway features

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: i think that list and its status is on some level a compromise between henri, who did not want to spam people with useless errors for markup that is in fact harmless, and ian, who wanted to alert authors of new documents that there are certain effectively useless constructs which they should not bother with

message.author: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea
message.text: yes, that's what i recall

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: i think the main reason for stray close tag to be an error is that there are a lot of authoring mistakes that would show up that way (forgetting to close a tag at all near some that may implicitly close, wrong close tag, misnested tags, etc)

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: 12470: contributor, p3, resolved fixed, in the last paragraph, please add the word "vertical", since the intent is apparently that _vertical_ margins at the top or bottom of body, td, or th elements be collapsed to zero. that's what browsers do in quirks mode. but horizontal margins are honored

message.text: also: there's no need, and certainly no particular desire, to map every element into aria semantics. they're just exposed when reasonable. elements carry their own semantics around without aria's help - the mapping table is used more to *restrict* what you can do with aria than anything else.

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: i don't really understand stuff like "plh: we sent advance notice to members for webapps charter ... the current version of that charter assumes that it's done at the ietf" about the origin header

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: cross-origin resource sharing is part of our charter and requires the origin header and we can introduce headers in w3c drafts as the provisional registry shows...

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: origin is not a beast, it's a very simple header...

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: yeah, but apparently we can't get that on standards track unless there is some wg

message.text: which seems like a lot of overhead for a header

message.author: e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0
message.text: well, i had to read up on them to learn what they exactly did, i've never used them anywhere... then again, i don't write banking applications and such

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: they're needed whenever you have multiple threads manipulating the same data, basically

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: e.g. if you want to update a row in one table to equal the results of processing another table

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: you don't want another thread editing the second table in between the select and the update

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: basically you'd have two completely separate gc roots

message.text: is your example basically <script>append a text node</script>x -- are there two text nodes or one?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: my confusion is with "firefox appends more text to the last text node it was appending to", since if a script is running, the last text node it inserted into was the <script>'s child node

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: you're saying you want <script>write 'aaa'; append element node</script>bbb to result in "aaabbb element node" rather than "aaa element node bbb"?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: and is the only behaviour i've found in the four browsers i tested that is even remotely sane.

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: anyway, as i noted in my e-mail reply, just use the text node's own buffer as the buffer

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: really? you don't think having things come out in the order they were written is sane?

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: you only get firefox's behaviour if you don't check to make sure the text node is still the last child each time a script runs

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: and i don't buy that it's hard to implement.

message.text: i think we should have a principle that says that evidence showing a feature _wouldn't_ or _doesn't_ work (e.g. the lack of use of profile="") should be taken into account

message.author: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
message.text: and i think we should have a principle that says that existing practices, where harmless or beneficial, should be adopted, rather than trying to swim upstream for purely theoretical reasons (or maybe the priority of constituencies priciple already covers that and just needs another example)

message.text: bugmail: [bug 12629] "the current value of the selectionend attribute as the first argument" -- you mean "second", not "first". <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0427.html> ** [bug 12223] drop rel=help. it's for showing a button in the browser's ui which no browser shows by default. it doesn't seem to be helpful for users, so just wastes authors' time. <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may

message.text: bugmail: "[bug 11162] select.size should either be web-compatible or make sense, take your pick" (2 messages in thread) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011jan/0660.html>

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: 11162: contributor, p3, resolved fixed, select.size should either be web-compatible or make sense, take your pick

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: dcf5500c7e53721d4b016e4793d5dd66: for radiobuttons, it is supposed to be per group

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: dcf5500c7e53721d4b016e4793d5dd66: short version, for checkbox, "required" requires each checkbox to be chacked, regardless of "name", for radio buttons, it's per group

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: if it was true for radio buttons, yeah

message.author: 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c
message.text: i think for radio buttons it works as you expect, for checkboxes, what the spec says sounds reasonable to me

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: changes: hixie: fix a couple of parser bugs that made valid es floating point numbers not get parsed to the same meaning in html attributes (whatwg r6084) <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-diffs/2011may/0040.html>

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: bugmail: [bug 12221] should structured clone preserve property descriptors? <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0287.html> ** [bug 12225] drop rel=tag. it doesn't seem to be used and doesn't seem to do anything useful. <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0286.html> ** [bug 11887] remove useless input.valueasnumber. pretty much the same functionality can be achieved using parsefloat or

message.author: 0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89
message.text: bugmail: [bug 12602] "<select><option>\n<option></select>" isn't a placeholder label option because its value is "\n", which is silly. we should strip spaces from the start and end in the definition of the option's label when it comes from textcontent. <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html-bugzilla/2011may/0310.html> ** [bug 12524] it would be nice if you could see the pretty glowing lines <http://lists.w3.org/archives/public/public-html
